text:
The Kwame Owusu-Kesse at
the Harlem Children's Zone

very much shaped
some of the research

that I'm doing, particularly
that around racial inequality.

And really thinking about
some of the tensions

that people face as they try to
make a difference in the world,

but also balance so many things
with different constituents

and stakeholders and people
that they care about.

I'm going to go with the classic
Erik Peterson, who I know
really sticks with students.

I think that's a really
helpful case for just thinking

about situations
where somebody is not
exercising a lot of agency.

The one case is
Rakuten because that's

a story about how this
organization is trying

to navigate and exert
their individual agency

against this broader
structural environment
that the company is seeing.

I will say Michael Ku and Global
Clinical Supply at Pfizer Inc.:
Bringing Hope to Patients.

Lynn Pain's case on Merck
Sharp and Dohme Argentina

got me to think
differently about research
on ethics in organizations.

It got me to focus
on how managers

solve complex
dilemmas, rather than
on why they end up doing wrong.

For me, the one case that
has kept my attention

for almost 20 years now is the
first case study I ever wrote.

It's called A Tale
of Two Coaches:

Bobby Knight and Coach
K. Twenty years later,

I'm learning more every time I
teach it, probably 10, 15 times
a year.

Is it better to be
loved or feared?

Still not sure exactly
what the answer is.
